Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: Hi had a few questions about KMD and the whitepaper.  It was extremely well written, the best whitepaper i've ever read imo. just wanted a little bit of clarification on the frequency of notary nodes winning blocks using the easy difficulty.  Is it basically one specific notary node will mine 1 block (and be rewarded 3KMD) out of every 64 KMD blocks, with the exception of the 2k block free-for-all period?

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: oh shoot cant post the screenshot of the whitepaper section

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content:
The notary nodes’ “easy difficulty” setting operates in a cyclical manner, with each notary node on its
own cycle. At the start of the cycle the notary node holds the “easy difficulty” ability until it mines one
“easy” block. Then the Iguana Core code removes the ability for the next sixty-four blocks. After the
sixty-four-block period passes, the notary node can once again attempt to capture a block on “easy
difficulty.”
Therefore, while everyone else on the network mines at an adjustable level of difficulty according to the
normal PoW consensus mechanism (which keeps the overall speed of the Komodo network stable) the
notary nodes have a chance to step outside the normal rules. For every sixty-five-block period on the
Komodo blockchain11, the odds that a block will be mined by a notary node, as opposed to a normal
miner, are essentially 3:1.

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: thats the section im trying to understand

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: can i interpret this as that a notary node has a 75% chance of winning a block in comparison to normal PoW miners? (excluding the free-for-all period)

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: No more free for all period, was changed in last update,  whitepaper needs updated. the reward split is the same 75/25.

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: ah ok thanks so its 75% to notary nodes though

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: and 25% to PoW?

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: isnt that a bit high...

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: its my understanding that 4 notary nodes are controlled by devs, 30 are auto-renewed each year and 30 are community elected.  Is there a list of who owns the 30 nodes that are auto-renewed?

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: The best 30 are renewed so notaries are incentivized to keep node up as much as possible.

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Bottom 30 spots are up for election

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: oh thats based on up time

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: can one person own multiple notary nodes?

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: or is there a limit?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Noyt exactly uptime

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: oh really

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The system rewards nodes who respond the fastest

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: There are many ways to game that.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: You can use a higher clockspeed CPU, or optimize software

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: so are the 30 picked subjectively by the devs?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: notarystats.com

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: https://komodostats.com/?day=today

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: that site counts ll notarizations and tallys them

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: @shiggidy if one has a loooot of kmd votes behind their team I suppose you could get multiple nodes elected

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: ah interesting

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: ALso the nodes location relative to other nodes seems very important... which IMO needs to be looked at, becasue to get auto elected all you need is to put your node in a DC where there are already heaps of nodes... which is very bad for network decentralisation.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: My node is a-team and is in Perth WA, the most isolated city int he world, and I have realy struggled to keep it competetive.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I am also using a 10 year old server though lol...

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: curious for any specific asset-chain what stops a 51% attack during the 10 minute interval that the notary nodes are performing their notarizing duties

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: a 51% attack on the asset-chain

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: if an altchain is submitting merkel roots to that asset-chain, is it possible that a malicious attacker could potentially 51% attack the altchain and the asset-chain simultaneously during that 10 minute window?

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: to double spend?

Author: shiggidy#4554
Content: especially since those asset-chains typically have low hash rates?

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: #ask-jl777 to ask @jl777c

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Or have one of the team answer

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I can answer that...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: There is nothing stopping you 51% attacking in between the 10 block KMD window. But timing it would be very difficult.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Most exchanges use a longer confirm time than 10 blocks anyway.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Its best to wait for a notarization to happen, to consider your transaction confirmed.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: if the TX is reorged out of the chain, you cna just make it again.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: or it should go back into the mempool anyway and get mined in a new block.
